moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. Nf3 Nbd7 6. Rc1 O-O 7. e3 b6 8. cxd5 exd5 9. Bd3
comment:
Some simple development moves have the particularity to provoke
some adrenalin discharges for the opponent. The move in the text is one of
them. The immediate aim of the Bishop on the pawn h7 is little assuring. 9...

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. Nf3 Nbd7 6. Rc1 O-O 7. e3 b6 8. cxd5 exd5 9. Bd3 Bb7 10. O-O c5 11. Re1 c4 12. Bb1
comment:
When such a Bishop goes and hide
himself in b1, his threat is enhanced since amateur chessplayers (not
professionals) have the tendency, after few moves, to forget his presence. It
seems that this Bishop, in such a remote corner, has a certain capability to
camouflage, so that some players are no longer able to see it, until when,
with a sudden release they see it to go out and bite their calves. A true
snake. 12...

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. Nf3 Nbd7 6. Rc1 O-O 7. e3 b6 8. cxd5 exd5 9. Bd3 Bb7 10. O-O c5 11. Re1 c4 12. Bb1 a6 13. Ne5 b5 14. f4 Re8 15. Qf3 Nf8
comment:
Going preventively
to further defend the pawn h7 without any resort of castle weakening moves,
such as h7-h6 or g7-g6.

Abandons th

29...

hope in the opponent's mistake: 52.Qf7+ Kh4 53.Qxb3 c1Q+ and mate in five.
